importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Gaza ceasefire deal was announced on October 8, 2025, and polling data collected shortly after (October 9–13) reflects public reaction to the agreement, which is central to understanding public sentiment toward President Trump’s foreign policy performance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from October 8 to October 20, 2025, marks the immediate aftermath of the Gaza ceasefire deal announcement and includes polling data that reveals public disapproval of Trump's handling of both foreign policy and the economy.

keyTakeAways: Despite the Gaza ceasefire deal being hailed as a major diplomatic achievement, American public approval of President Donald Trump remains low, with disapproval rates at their highest levels in his second term.
Trump's approval rating on the Gaza issue rose slightly (to 47% approval from 37% in September), but disapproval remained strong at 49% in the AP-NORC poll, indicating minimal public enthusiasm.

In the CNBC poll, Americans disapproved of Trump on Gaza 50% to 41%, and on the economy 52% to 44%, with the economy showing a net disapproval of 13 points — his worst rating on economic performance in either term.
Americans are increasingly pessimistic about the economy, with only 32% expecting economic improvement and 31% expecting wage increases over the next year, signaling widespread economic anxiety.
The percentage of employed Americans not worried about job loss has dropped to 52%, lower than any point during the final three years of the Biden administration.
Public concern over inflation and the cost of living has reached a new low, with 62% disapproving of Trump’s handling of inflation and the cost of living.
Foreign policy issues, including the Gaza deal, are low on Americans' priority list; only 4% in a CBS News-YouGov poll ranked international events as the most important issue facing the country.
Three-fourths of Americans believe Trump has not done enough to lower prices, suggesting economic issues outweigh foreign policy concerns in public opinion.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Despite President Donald Trump’s announcement of a Gaza ceasefire deal being seen as a major diplomatic victory, American public opinion reveals little enthusiasm. Polling data from late October 2025 shows that while Trump’s approval on Gaza slightly increased, disapproval remains high — with overall approval of his leadership at a historic low. His economic performance, particularly on inflation and the cost of living, is viewed far more negatively than his foreign policy achievements. Public anxiety over economic conditions, such as job security and wage growth, is rising, and foreign policy is ranked low in national priorities. These dynamics suggest that Americans are largely indifferent to the Gaza deal, placing much greater weight on domestic economic issues, which may ultimately define Trump’s political standing.
title: Americans shrug at Trump’s Gaza deal, as economic fears reign
